ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge on the history of American romcoms from screwball comedies to the present day. Learned about film analysis, black love on screen, and challenges romcoms face in terms of public perception.
I learned how to critical evaluate romantic comedies and other films
Ways of thinking about romance. Cavell was very generative. Questions about genre, as well
I learned how to think more critically about cinematic representations of love.
Under Professor Forster's guidance, I learned more than I ever thought I could. We discussed and read about romance, race, gender, film theory, film tropes and trends, actors, etc.
I learned a lot about film and how philosophy could be applied to film and African American studies. I also became a better writer.

I learned a ton. I learned how to watch movies (and to an extent popular media more broadly) as rich and meaningful texts. I feel like I got better at navigating difficult conversations. All in all this was a really enriching experience

I left this class with more knowledge of the conventions and history of romanic comedies. I now have a better understanding of what love looks like on screen and pay attention to elements I never noticed before in romance films.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The course has an excellent syllabus. The films we watched were great  I've never taken a film class at Yale with such enjoyable movies. Even the films I didn't like were interesting and sparked good discussions. Prof. Forster is also great about giving thoughtful and in-depth feedback on everything you submit. 
The main weakness of the course was that sometimes class felt a little stunted. It was often hard for us to find a rhythm as a class and even though Prof. Forster always came prepared with discussion questions, sometimes those discussion questions made us veer even further off track or made people feel hesitant to speak. I think a lot of this awkwardness would go away in person, though.

Strengths: the films!! Prof. Forster picked out a great set of films to watch. The blog posts and papers were also so fun to write, I hate writing in general but I really really enjoyed these assignments. Weakness: maybe the readings. It was quite a bit of work in the beginning, but once Prof. Forster made some of the readings suggested it became much more manageable.

Strengths: presentations were a good way to stay engaged. I think the chat function was actually very fruitful in this class. Since Zoom school I think this is the only class I've taken where the chat function actually enriched the course. I also think the Tuesday film/TV confessions bit was great for encouraging participation. 

2 films/week was kinda a lot sometimes, especially with reading due for each class. I think that combined with the blog posts was a lot.
This course is really reading heavy, and at times the workload felt a little overwhelming/unmanageable (even though I really was trying to keep up and be an active student).

The only weakness was that she of the readings were very dense and philosophical which I had trouble understanding so on those weeks it was a little difficult to keep up with multiple readings and a film. However, one of the main strengths was that Prof Forster adjusted the syllabus based off of our feedback and so that got much better by week 4. The strengths was that the readings and films were amazing. Also Prof Forster asked really great questions and was very receptive to us.

I think the film selection and discussions were really really strong. Sometimes I wished the essays had fewer specific requirements, and were a little bit more open ended, so we could explore a little more broadly, but I also felt that the constraints helped strengthen my writing.

The films are the greatest strength of this course. We watched a lot of films that you wouldn't find in other film classes. The readings are interesting, but could sometimes be very dense and we wouldn't always have time to get to each of them in class. Being able to watch the films together and discuss in person would have been great for this class as discussion over Zoom was sometimes difficult.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Student presentations were very helpful at summarizing the readings and the films and were a good addition to the start of classes on Zoom. I also appreciated when Prof. Foster polled the class and decided to make one of the sessions asynchronous, giving us a break from online classes for the week.
It was difficult feeling engaged in this seminar, but I think it had more to do with the virtual setting and the students.
I don't know if you will be using Zoom next year, but it could be cool to have virtual class screenings?
Zoom worked, especially because Prof Forster really used the chat and poll function.
I think small Zoom discussions are pretty effective. Ive never been a fan of breakout rooms though.

The individual presentations were helpful in dissecting some difficult readings and posing interesting questions to get discussion started. Rewatching clips together was another good tool to go over specific scenes and break up discussion. The couple mess we used the whiteboard and annotate functions on Zoom were fun and allowed everyone to chime in and could have been used more often.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student. It is a good film class for students interested in the topic but afraid of taking a course in the film department. The workload is very fair and the films are easy to engage with. Some of the readings are a little difficult, but Prof. Forster was aware of that and tried to walk us through them. I think the course would be much better in person where in-person class can really benefit from the seminar style.

I would!!! Sometimes the workload felt like a lot but Professor Forster was incredibly accommodating, and who else can say they watch rom coms for class? It was definitely one of those classes where you got out what you put into it.

For those interested in learning about desirability and romance, this is the class to take. I think the focus on old Hollywood was also really helpful as someone interested in familiarizing myself with film history.
If you love or are even ambivalent about rom-coms, you should take the course!
Yes. Yes. Yes. A thousand times yes.
Yes, it was a great way to learn more critically about films many of us already loved.
Yes absolutely! If youre looking for a film class or just interested in the intersections of love, media, and politics, this is a wonderful course.
Yes. Watching and discussing romantic comedies with classmates is something other film classes don't offer.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Online Zoom seminar.
Office hours, optional virtual one-on-one meetings
We also could use an online service that let us ask questions on readings and blog posts where we could see our classmates thoughts.
None

extras.title:
FILM 252 01/AFAM 262 01
        Rom Coms and Cinematic Romance
